results.title: Religion and magic
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Man’s quest for meaning, coupled with the idea of an ultimate reality beyond daily existence is evident in all societies. Religion explains the unknown, provides a common purpose and values for a community, helps weave all elements of society into one design and provides world views and belief systems that give meaning to all that humanity is and does. Religions can express harmony and balance, as with the North American Indians and Balinese Hinduism. Religions can be modified as cultures interact, can descend into magic and shamanism, or, as in industrialised society be relegated to special occasions or banned altogether. Although science seems to provide answers it is said that “the cosmos looks more and more like a great thought”. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Relatives (AFC)
results.creator_credit: Antony J. Bowman, Basil Appleby, Henri Safran, Archer Films and Quantum Films
results.brief_description: Set in beautiful cattle farming country New South Wales during the 1980s, this quirky comedy drama centres around a family reunion to celebrate grandfather’s 80th birthday. Spanning three generations, the relatives all gather at the historical family homestead, some from the city and others from the country. Add to this an intruder from Czechoslovakia, lots of alcohol, family jealousies and rivalries, “dangerous” liaisons, a somewhat bewildered and bemused grandfather, and an important announcement which will affect the whole family, there can be only one outcome - disaster. Cast includes Bill Kerr, Rowena Wallace, Carol Raye, Ray Barrett and Norman Kaye. Music written and played by Norman Kaye and photography by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Relative strangers
results.brief_description: Family ties are often a fragile thing, as Simon is about to discover as he unravels the secrets of one man’s childhood. A haunting look at the issues facing modern family life.

results.title: Regulating body temperature
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Compares ecto and endotherms. Discusses convection, conduction, radiation and insulation. Also mechanisms of sweating and shivering, and behavioural patterns relating to heat regulation. Humidity is discussed along with the role of the hypothalamus. Highlights the necessity of correct core temperature.

results.title: Refuse to Dance : The Theatre of Howard Barker
results.creator_credit: Ann Foreman and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: This film focuses on the season of Barker’s work produced by the Royal Shakespeare Company at the Barbican in 1985. It juxtaposes extracts from the plays with comments from actors, directors and critics. However, it makes no attempt to pin an evaluation of the work to the personality or biography of the writer.

results.title: Refrigeration and air conditioning
results.brief_description: Illustrates the basic concept that evaporation is a cooling process. A model refrigerator with plastic coils shows how, through a continuous cycle of evaporation and condensation of a refrigerant, heat is absorbed from inside the insulated box and released outside. The same principles are seen in air conditioning systems, and convection currents are illustrated.

results.title: Refraction
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and J. Arthur Rank
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Light”.
Considers a ray of light passing through a rectangular slab of glass, offering the analogy of wheels, running on to a bed of sand. Illustrates refraction through a prism; water to air refraction; total internal refraction; right-angled prisms; the periscope and binoculars.

results.title: Reflections on time
results.creator_credit: Giancarlo Lui and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Introduces small and large units of time, and suggests that perhaps time is motion or life. The second part stresses the fact that we measure time by motion and vice-versa, gicing examples of various clocks. The third part illustrates the vastness of time using the Grand Canyon and the Galaxy of Andromeda.
